quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Does anything genuinely beautiful need supplementing? No more than justice does- or truth, or kindness, or humility. Are any of those improved by being praised? Or damaged by contempt? Is an emerald suddenly flawed if no one admires it?
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: So there are two reasons to embrace what happens. One is that it's happening to you. It was prescribed for you, and it pertains to you. The thread was spun long ago, by the oldest cause of all.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: But true good fortune is what you make for yourself. Good fortune: good character, good intentions, and good actions.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Today I escaped from anxiety. Or no, I discarded it, because it was within me, in my own perceptions- not outside.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: When faced with people's bad behavior, turn around and ask when you have acted like that. When you saw money as a good, or pleasure, or social position. Your anger will subside as soon as you recognize that they acted under compulsion (what else could they do?)
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: That kindness is invincible, provided it's sincere- not ironic or an act. What can even the most vicious person do if you keep treating him with kindness and gently set him straight
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: When you start to lose your temper, remember: There's nothing manly about rage. It's courtesy and kindness that define a human being- and a man. That's who possesses strength and nerves and guts, not the angry whiners.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: We almost never teach or learn when arguing.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: He who has more money or possessions than you is not necessarily happier than you, happy more often than you, or happy like you.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Intelligent people question everything. Stupid people answer every question.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Most people would rather believe something that is not true about something than accept the fact that they do not understand a thing about that thing.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Most people want more than they have without having made the most of what they have.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: That we can change the shadow of an object without changing the object (by changing the position of the source of light) reminds us that we can change how we feel about a situation or person by changing only how we look at it or them.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: It is a humbling practice to make a mental note whenever your assumption turns out to be wrong.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: We live life passively whenever we are not practicing mindfulness.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: A truth whispered is not less truthful. And an untruth shouted is not less untruthful.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Some people are lucky to no longer be, and some are unlucky to still be, alive.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Some of our problems came to us; some, we went to them.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Destroying your mirrors leaves your facial blemishes intact.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: You can be invincible, if you enter into no contest in which it is not in your power to conquer.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The problem with pleasure is that it needs to be intermittent in order to retain its pleasantness.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: It is foolish to give up on yourself. And doubly so to do that before everyone has given up on you.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Fools refuse to truly believe that a thing can be both delicious or pleasurable … and harmful.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: 99.99% of fools deny their foolishness. The rest underestimate it.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: When conversing, some people regularly stop talking, not to listen, but to rest their tongues.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: You are indeed a man of sorrows and have suffered much...pray be seated now, here on this chair, and let us leave our sorrows, bitter though they are, locked up in our own hearts, for weeping is cold comfort and does little good.
quotes.author: Homer

quotes.text: Let death and exile and every other thing which appears dreadful be daily before your eyes; but most of all death: and you will never think of anything mean nor will you desire anything extravagantly.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Destroying your mirrors hides your ugliness or facial blemishes from only you.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Some of the people who we think care that we hate them do not even care that there are people who love them.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Sometimes you find yourself so grateful that a prayer of yours was not answered that you pray that it be ignored. Just in case it is on the waiting list of prayers to be answered.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: A desired thing often comes with seeds of at least one desire.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: How does a person deal with all the heartache and tragedy that fills their life without becoming insane or committing suicide?
quotes.author: Kilroy J Oldster

quotes.text: When you are unhappy, happy people are disgusting.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Sometimes silence is a sign, not of not knowing what to say, but of knowing when to say what you know.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: When you are alone, you should call this tranquility and freedom and when you are with many you shouldn't call this a crowd, or trouble or uneasiness but festival and company and contentedly accept it.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Poverty is greatly exaggerated by sanity.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: We get a taste of death, not when we're asleep, but when we awake.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Like great ecologists, great pessimists make us see the beauty of death.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: We subconsciously wish that all of the things we hate but our enemies love were harmful.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Admitting that their child is, or can be, more educated than them is the closest most parents are willing to get to admitting that their child is, or can be, smarter or wiser than them.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Imagine smiling after a slap in the face. Then think of doing it twenty-four hours a day.
quotes.author: Markus Zusak

quotes.text: If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it; and this you have the power to revoke at any moment.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it, if you have to, with the same weapons of reason which today arm you against the present.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Warriors should suffer their pain silently.
quotes.author: Erin Hunter

quotes.text: It is the power of the mind to be unconquerable.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Complaining does not work as a strategy. We all have finite time and energy. Any time we spend whining is unlikely to help us achieve our goals. And it won't make us happier.
quotes.author: Randy Pausch

quotes.text: Until we have begun to go without them, we fail to realize how unnecessary many things are. We've been using them not because we needed them but because we had them.
quotes.author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quotes.text: People hide their truest nature. I understood that; I even applauded it. What sort of world would it be if people bled all over the sidewalks, if they wept under trees, smacked whomever they despised, kissed strangers, revealed themselves?

quotes.text: A Stoic is someone who transforms fear into prudence, pain into transformation, mistakes into initiation, and desire into undertaking.
quotes.author: Taleb Nassim Nicholas

quotes.text: Feeling too much is a hell of a lot better than feeling nothing.
quotes.author: Nora Roberts

quotes.text: How do you defeat terrorism? Don't be terrorized.
quotes.author: Salman Rushdie

quotes.text: Always resignation and acceptance. Always prudence and honour and duty. Elinor, where is your heart?

quotes.text: The things you think about determine the quality of your mind.

quotes.text: Misfortune nobly born is good fortune.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You should … live in such a way that there is nothing which you could not as easily tell your enemy as keep to yourself.
quotes.author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quotes.text: Nothing is burdensome if taken lightly, and nothing need arouse one's irritation so long as one doesn't make it bigger than it is by getting irritated.

quotes.text: What really frightens and dismays us is not external events themselves, but the way in which we think about them. It is not things that disturb us, but our interpretation of their significance.

quotes.text: There will never come a time when I will be able to resist my emotions.
quotes.author: Louise Erdrich

quotes.text: I hear my silence talked of in every lane; The suppression of a cry is itself a cry of pain.

quotes.text: You will never see me surrender, never see me cry, but you will often see me walk away. Turn around and just leave, without looking back.

quotes.text: Soon, you will have forgotten everything.  Soon, everybody will have forgotten you.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Sometimes, even to live is an act of courage.

quotes.text: The willing are led by fate, the reluctant are dragged.

quotes.text: Death devours not only those who have been cooked by old age; it also feasts on those who are half-cooked and even those who are raw.

quotes.text: Being a stoic does not mean being a robot. Being a stoic means remaining calm both at the height of pleasure and the depths of misery.

quotes.text: We might never rid ourselves of a lingering anxiety regarding our death; this is a kind of tax we pay in return for self-awareness.

quotes.text: Everything worthwhile in your life draws its meaning from the fact you will die.

quotes.text: That which Fortune has not given, she cannot take away.
quotes.author: Seneca the Younger

quotes.text: Life is how you look at it.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Yes, as my swift days near their goal, 'Tis all that I implore - In life and death, a chainless soul, With courage to endure.

quotes.text: When others inspire us, they tend to do so through the clear expression of these sketchy, adumbrated thoughts we ourselves have known but never had the perspicacity for formulate with certainty.
quotes.author: Derren Brown

quotes.text: Sometimes we have no luxury of choice. We must do certain things for survival. That should not stop us from doing the things we love.

quotes.text: It takes courage to speak or react way slower than you think.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: When you are disturbed by events and lose your serenity, quickly return to yourself and don't stay upset longer than the experience lasts; for you'll have more mastery over your inner harmony by continually returning to it.

quotes.text: You should, I need hardly say, live in such a way that there is nothing which you could not as easily tell your enemy as keep to yourself.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The supreme ideal does not call for any external aids. It is homegrown, wholly self-developed. Once it starts looking outside itself for any part of itself it is on the way to being dominated by fortune.

quotes.text: The man who looks for the morrow without worrying over it knows a peaceful independence and a happiness beyond all others. Whoever has said, "I have lived' receives a windfall every day he gets up in the morning.

quotes.text: Show me a man who though sick is happy, who though in danger is happy, who though in prison is happy, and I'll show you a Stoic.

quotes.text: They did this to me but I have remained who I am. I am tempered. I am able. Inside myself there's an untouched man. If they came back now, and did everything to me again, they would never reach the untouched man. I've passed the exam I've been shirking all my life. I'm a graduate of pain.

quotes.text: The Sage desires only one thing, virtue, and he is cautious about only one thing, vice. He is the same in every circumstance because what is most important lies within him, and not with external events, which are constantly changing.

quotes.text: Making noble resolutions is not as important as keeping the resolutions you have made already. (Letter XVI)

quotes.text: The most fruitful breaks are often those we are or were forced to take by life.

quotes.text: Appreciating what you have is the best cure for missing what you have lost.

quotes.text: Soon you will be dead and none of it will matter
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: man was given two ears and one mouth for a reason

quotes.text: I sacrificed much to be where I am today, yet I will sacrifice much more to get to where I need to be someday.

quotes.text: Stoicism is designed to be medicine for the soul.

quotes.text: A shallow reading of a problem begets outrage; a detailed approach to a problem encourages moderation.

quotes.text: Education teaches us how to make a living, not how to live.

quotes.text: Like a problem, time is nothing but a shadow of thought.

quotes.text: Halleck came from people who regarded a slight change of facial expression as adequate to convey the pain of a severed limb.

quotes.text: See? You're using the stoic glacier method."  "Remind me, what's the stoic glacier method?"  "It's the slow process of shaping someone's behavior by force of one's own personal stoicism.

quotes.text: Life is a pilgrimage and a struggle. All we have of time is a moment; the universe is in constant flux; our bodies are fragile; our senses grasp so little; our souls are a mist; the future is a fog; and fame is fleeting.

quotes.text: There was no meaning in why he was here, but he was, and that was enough.

quotes.text: Growth is often the cause or the result of pain.

quotes.text: What progress, you ask, have I made? I have begun to be a friend to myself.

quotes.text: We all have problems. Or rather, everyone has at least one thing that they regard as a problem.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: True affluence is not needing anything.

quotes.text: Death would not surprise us as often as it does, if we let go of the misbelief that newborns are less mortal than the elderly.

quotes.text: Man is mostly a collection of emotions, most of which he would do better not to be feeling.

quotes.text: Progress daily in your own uncertainty. Live in awareness of the questions.

quotes.text: It is not the man who has too little who is poor, but the one who hankers after more.

quotes.text: Most of us are “living the dream” living, that is, the dream we once had for ourselves.

quotes.text: Seek not for events to happen as you wish but rather wish for events to happen as they do and your life will go smoothly.

quotes.text: What would Heracles have been if he had said, "How am I to prevent a big lion from appearing, or a big boar, or brutal men?" What care you, I say? If a big boar appears, you will have a greater struggle to engage in; if evil men appear, you will free the world from evil men.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It was as if I'd lost some cosmic game of musical chairs; the song had stopped, I was left standing, and there was simply nothing to be dine about it.

quotes.text: When you give your items away, don't keep the excess of your pride.

quotes.text: If you have assumed any character beyond your strength, you have both demeaned yourself ill in that and quitted one which you might have supported.

quotes.text: The bigger the family, the bigger the number of corpses it owes life.

quotes.text: Growth is often the parent or the child of pain.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Let whatever appears to be the best be to you an inviolable law. And if any instance of pain or pleasure, glory or disgrace, be set before you, remember that now is the combat, now the Olympiad comes on, nor can it be put off; and that by one failure and defeat honor may be lost or—won.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Once you start learning from your problems, you stop wishing for a life without problems.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: For a delight in bustling about is not industry - it is only the restless energy of a hunted mind. And the state of mind that looks on all activity as tiresome is not true repose, but a spineless inertia.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Destroying the seeds of disappointment requires you to unexpect the expected.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Cling tooth and nail to the following rule: not to give in to adversity, never to trust prosperity, and always take full not of fortune's habit of behaving just as she pleases, treating her as if she were actually going to do everything it is in her power to do.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: If someone in the street were entrusted with your body, you would be furious. Yet you entrust your mind to anyone around who happens to insult you, and allow it to be troubled and confused. Aren't you ashamed of that?

quotes.text: The most effective way to understand the dissonance between our thoughts about reality and reality itself, is to consider how many times we've felt like our world is ending and how many times it actually has.

quotes.text: I began to care a lot less about embarrassment after running into somebody who for months, I feared I would, and realizing afterward that my life was no different after the encounter than before.
quotes.author: Daniel V Chappell

quotes.text: The present is the same for everyone; its loss is the same for everyone; and it should be clear that a brief instant is all that is lost. For you can't lose either the past or the future; how could you lose what you don't have?

quotes.text: We always have a choice as to, not what we hear, but what we listen to.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: The weaker the desire to change, the further away from now is the moment from which we plan on changing.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: For a life spent viewing all the variety, the majesty, the sublimity in things around us can never succumb to ennui: the feeling that one is tired of being, of existing, is usually the result of an idle and inactive leisure.

quotes.text: Pleasures, when they go beyond a certain limit, are but punishments.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Running is a form of practiced stoicism. It means teaching your brain and body to be biochemically comfortable in a state of disrepair.

quotes.text: Even in the longest life real living is the least portion thereof.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: If a discrepancy exists between supply and demand, then for the Stoics the prescription for a happy life was to decrease demand, not to increase supply (or production), which the Hedonists saw as the prescription for a happy life.
quotes.author: Tomáš Sedláček

quotes.text: Disturbance comes only from within- from our own perceptions. Everything you see will soon alter and cease to exist
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Is the child or wife of another dead? There is no one who would not say, “This is an accident of mortality.” But if anyone's own child happens to die, it is immediately, “Alas! how wretched am I!” It should be always remembered how we are affected on hearing the same thing concerning others.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: We often do not, not because we cannot, but because we think so.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: It's with a heavy heart that I assure you that regardless of how lasting your fortune feels, it can be taken from you before you can even think to try to hold on.
quotes.author: Daniel V Chappell

quotes.text: We're never unhappy until we remember why we're supposed to be unhappy.
quotes.author: Daniel V Chappell

quotes.text: A fool is a man who disregards legacy.
quotes.author: Daniel V Chappell

quotes.text: We must become friends of despair if we are to be drawn above it to genuine and heartfelt hope. Far from being  an exercise in morbidity or arrogance, a deepening acquaintance with our  death and with the vanity of human wishes is our worldly hearts a  needed path to perfect health.
quotes.author: Robert Campbell Roberts

quotes.text: Christianity is not a therapy for those who wish never to be upset (177).
quotes.author: Robert Campbell Roberts

quotes.text: Love me for my affection, love me even for my weakness; I am satisfied myself. I prefer my feelings to all the fine sentiments of Seneca or Epictetus.
quotes.author: Marie Rabutin-Chantal De Sevigne

quotes.text: It is human to be angry, but childish to be controlled by anger.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: You can be hurt, not by what others think of you, but by what you think of what they think or you think they think of you.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: A man is as unhappy as he has convinced himself he is.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The mind is inclined to zoom in on your problem, or few problems, to an extend that you cannot see your many blessings.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: The probability of something not happening does not decrease as we increase the number of times we worry about the possibility of it happening.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Increasing the strength of our minds is the only way to reduce the difficulty of life.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: It takes patience to nurture patience.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Not even once has life or the weather complained about a human being.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: It is childish to be surprised by something that you knew exists or is possible.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Optimism is an effort.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: When pain comes, it must not derail you from your set virtues. If it does, you have failed to practice your virtues by going with the hype of pain.

quotes.text: I've let people's opinions, my own self judgements and many negative things take this life away from me. No more!
quotes.author: Tiisetso Maloma

quotes.text: A man whose mind has completely left childhood behind would not be surprised if he were to walk in on his wife having sex with her father … or with his mother.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Change: nothing inherently bad in the process, nothing inherently good in the result.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Every second is a step away from our mothers' wombs towards our own tombs.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Most people will leave you with the impression that the main function of our emotions is to cloud our judgement.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: We are generally pleased the most by compliments that are insincere.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: That you have just caught success after chasing it for many years does not mean that death will stop chasing you for at least a few seconds.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: If you lose today every-day, you are lost every-day.
quotes.author: Tiisetso Maloma

quotes.text: Tomorrow will take care of itself, so take care of today, otherwise tomorrow will take ill-care of you today – thus losing today.
quotes.author: Tiisetso Maloma

quotes.text: Tomorrow's worries contaminate the present.
quotes.author: Tiisetso Maloma

quotes.text: What are virtues, if not practiced evenly in both times of joy and in hardships?
quotes.author: Tiisetso Maloma

quotes.text: I value my time so much that undressing is the only thing I am willing to do for sex.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: Having problems is not nearly as tormenting as being had by problems.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: She looks as if she were thinking of something beyond her punishment—beyond her situation: of something not round nor before her.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: ...when I asked him if he forgave me, he answered that he was not in the habit of cherishing the remembrance of vexation; that he had nothing to forgive; not having been offended.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: The older you are, and the faster you walk, the crazier you look.
quotes.author: Mokokoma Mokhonoana

quotes.text: You have power over your mind - not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: It is not so much what happens to you as how you think about what happens.

quotes.text: It is not that we have so little time but that we lose so much. ... The life we receive is not short but we make it so; we are not ill provided but use what we have wastefully.

quotes.text: It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.

quotes.text: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.

quotes.text: If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you're needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person.

quotes.text: He who is brave is free

quotes.text: Until we have begun to go without them, we fail to realize how unnecessary many things are. We've been using them not because we needed them but because we had them.

quotes.text: What need is there to weep over parts of life? The whole of it calls for tears.

quotes.text: No man was ever wise by chance

quotes.text: They lose the day in expectation of the night, and the night in fear of the dawn.

quotes.text: Associate with people who are likely to improve you.

quotes.text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.

quotes.text: I shall never be ashamed of citing a bad author if the line is good.

quotes.text: Only time can heal what reason cannot.

quotes.text: Most powerful is he who has himself in his own power.

quotes.text: The wise man, he said, lacked nothing but needed a great number of things, whereas 'the fool, on the other hand, needs nothing (for he does not know how to use anything) but lack everything.

quotes.text: For what can be above the man who is above fortune?

quotes.text: The past is ours, and there is nothing more secure for us than that which has been. We are ungrateful for past gains, because we hope for the future, as if the future – if so be that any future is ours – will not be quickly blended with the past.

quotes.text: But every great and overpowering grief must take away the capacity to choose words, since it often stifles the voice itself.

quotes.text: This evil of taking our cue from others has become so deeply ingrained that even that most basic feeling, grief, degenerates into imitation.

quotes.text: No man is so faint-hearted that he would rather hang in suspense for ever than drop once for all.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: this will not be a gentle prescription for healing, but cautery and the knife. What shall I achieve? That a soul which has conquered so many miseries will be ashamed to worry about one more wound in a body which already has so many scars.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: That which takes effect by chance is not an art.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Above all, my dear Lucilius, make this your business: learn how to feel joy.

quotes.text: For those who follow nature everything is easy and straightforward, whereas for those who fight against her life is just like rowing against the stream.

quotes.text: What really ruins our characters is the fact that none of us looks back over his life. We think about what we are going to do, and only rarely of that, and fail to think about what we have done, yet any plans for the future are dependent on the past.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: We Stoics are not subjects of a despot: each of us lays claim to his own freedom.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: But it is one thing to remember, another to know. Remembering is merely safeguarding something entrusted to the memory; knowing, however, means making everything your own; it means not depending upon the copy and not all the time glancing back at the master.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Undisturbed by fears and unspoiled by pleasures, we shall be afraid neither of death nor the gods.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: He who needs riches least, enjoys riches most.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is not the man who has too little who is poor, but the one who hankers after more.

quotes.text: But consider whether you may not get more help from the customary method than from that which is now commonly called a "breviary," though in the good old days, when real Latin was spoken, it was called a "summary."

quotes.text: Life's finest day for wretched mortals here Is always first to flee.

quotes.text: You will notice that the most powerful and highly stationed men let drop remarks in which they pray for leisure, praise it, and rate it higher than all their blessings.

quotes.text: When one is busy and absorbed in one's work, the very absorption affords great delight; but when one has withdrawn one's hand from the completed masterpiece, the pleasure is not so keen.

quotes.text: For we are not summoned according to the paristi register And besides there is no man so old as to make it sinful to expect another day. Now every day is another step in life.

quotes.text: Divine seeds are scattered throughout our mortal bodies;

quotes.text: There's thunder even on the loftiest peaks.

quotes.text: You squander time as if you drew from a full and abundant supply, though all the while that day which you bestow on some person or thing is perhaps your last.  You have all the fears of mortals and all the desires of immortals.

quotes.text: It is too late to begin living life just as it is ending! What stubborn denial of mortality to delay dreams to after your fiftieth and sixtieth year, and to plan on starting your life at a point that not everyone gets to.

quotes.text: One has to accept life on the same terms as the public baths, or crowds, or travel.

quotes.text: The reason is unwillingness, the excuse, inability.

quotes.text: Part of my joy in learning is that it puts me in a position to teach; nothing, however outstanding and however helpful, will ever give me any pleasure if the knowledge is to be for my benefit alone.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Regard everything that pleases you as if it were a flourishing plant; make the most of it while it is in leaf, for different plants at different seasons must fall and die.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is absurd," he says, "to run towards death because you are tired of life, when it is your manner of life that has made you run towards death.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: the happy life depends upon this and this alone: our attainment of perfect reason.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: In guarding their fortune men are often close-fisted, yet, when it comes to the matter of wasting time, in the case of the one thing in which it is right to be miserly, they show themselves most prodigal.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: One day is equal to every day.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Awake, my heart, And do such deeds as in the time to come No tongue shall praise, but none refuse to tell.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: What is the happy life? It is peace of mind, and lasting tranquillity. This will be yours if you possess greatness of soul; it will be yours if you possess the steadfastness that resolutely clings to a good judgment just reached.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Great things cannot be bought for small sums.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Rehearse them in your mind: exile, torture, war, shipwreck. All the terms of our human lot should be before our eyes.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: At last, then, away with all these treacherous goods! They look better to those who hope for them than to those who have attained them.
quotes.author: Seneca
